metadata.title: Human mastadenovirus-B (HAdV-B)-specific E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ glycoproteins interact with each other and localize at the plasma membrane of non-polarized airway epithelial cells Human mastadenovirus-B (HAdV-B)-specific E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ glycoproteins interact

abstract.text: Please cite this article as: Lakshmi Narayan, P.K., Kajon, A.E., Human mastadenovirus-B (HAdV-B)-specific E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ glycoproteins interact with each other and localize at the plasma membrane of non-polarized airway epithelial cells, Virology (2020), doi: https://doi.

body_text.text: Human adenoviruses (HAdV) encompass more than 90 genotypes that are classified into 7 39 species designated Human mastadenovirus A through G (HAdV-A through -G) (Espinola et al., 40 death protein/ADP) facilitates virus progeny release from infected cells at late stages of 83 infection. (Tollefson et al., 1996a; Tollefson et al., 1996b; Zou et al., 2004) . 84 The genomes of all simian and human types classified within species HAdV-B encode two 85 unique E3-CR1 genes designated CR1β and CR1γ which are believed to have arisen by gene 86 duplication (Signas et al., 1986) . As shown in Figure 1 , the genomes of some subspecies HAdV-87 B1 types encode a third highly polymorphic E3-CR1 gene designated CR1δ (Frietze et al., 2010; 88 Kajon et al., 2005) . These 3 genes have very low sequence similarity to any other known AdV 89 genes or to other sequences in the NCBI/GenBank database, making sequence-based prediction 90 of biological function challenging.

This paper presents the results of our initial characterization of the proteins encoded by the 92 HAdV-B specific E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ genes using HAdV-3 as a model. 95 The sequences of E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ ORFs encoded by various human and simian types 117 vectors 118 For our studies, we generated a HAdV-3 mutant virus encoding small epitope tags at the N-119 termini of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K (HAdV-3 N-tag wt) and a double knock-out (DKO) mutant 120 virus that cannot express . FIGREF5.text: Plaque assay 249 Confluent A549 cells seeded in a 6-well plate were infected with 100 µl of serially diluted 250 virus sample. After adsorption for 1 h at 37°C cell monolayers were overlaid with 1.4% low melt 251 agarose (G-Biosciences, St. Louis, MO Cat# RC-008) mixed with an equal volume of 2X MEM 252 supplemented with 4% HI-NBCS, 4.0 mM L-glutamine (Corning Inc., Corning NY Cat#: 25-253 005-CI), and 20 U/ml penicillin, 20 µg/ml streptomycin (Corning Inc., Corning NY Cat# 30-002-CI) and, 25 mM MgCl 2 . The agarose overlay was allowed to solidify at room temperature for 20 255 minutes. A second overlay was applied 4 days pi. At 8 days pi the infected monolayers were 256 fixed with 1% formaldehyde in 0.15 M NaCl and stained with crystal violet after removal of the 257 agarose overlay plug. Cell monolayers were then washed and air-dried, and the plaques were 258 counted. Infectious virus titers were determined in technical triplicates and expressed as pfu/ml.

FIGREF6.text: Virus progeny release assay 260 Confluent A549 cells seeded in a 35 mm dish were infected with HAdV-3 wt, HAdV-3 N-tag 261 wt, or HAdV-3 N-tag DKO at a MOI of 1 pfu/cell. At different times pi supernatants from 262 infected cell monolayers (extracellular virus) were collected, transferred to a 15 ml conical tube 263 and spun down at 1000 rpm for 10 mins to remove floating cells and cell debris. For assessment 264 of total infectious virus loads, cell monolayers along with the corresponding supernatants were 265 transferred to a 15 ml conical and subjected to 3 cycles of freeze-thaw at -80°C. The suspension 266 was then clarified by spinning at 1000 rpm for 10 mins to remove cell debris. Infectious virus 267 titers were then determined by plaque assay on A549 cells as described above. Three 268 independent experiments were performed and each experiment had biological triplicates.

FIGREF7.text: Virus dissemination assay270    Virus dissemination (a.k.a. spread) assays were performed as described(Doronin et al.,   271   2003). Briefly, confluent A549 cells seeded in a 24-well dish were infected with HAdV-3 wt,272 HAdV-3 N-tag wt, or HAdV-3 N-tag DKO at MOIs of 10, 1, 0.1, 0.01, and 0.001 pfu/cell. At 7 273 days pi the cells were fixed with 4% formaldehyde in 0.15 M NaCl and stained with crystal 274 violet for visualization of cytopathic effect. described above. At 8 days pi, the plaques were imaged at 4X magnification with an 279 CKX41 Olympus microscope equipped with an Infinity 2-3 digital camera (Teledyne Lumenera, 280 Canada) using the Infinity Capture software. ImageJ software (https://imagej.net) was used to 281 measure the diameter of 70 plaques for each of the examined viruses.

FIGREF8.text: Statistical analysis 283 All experiments were performed in biological triplicates. Graph Pad Prism V5 was used to 284 conduct statistical analyses. Statistical significance was evaluated by one-way ANOVA and 285Bonferroni post-hoc test. A p value of <0.05 was considered significant.

FIGREF10.text: E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ are conserved among human and simian members of species289    HAdV-B290    The alignment of predicted polypeptide sequences of E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ encoded by 291 various HAdV-B types revealed that the two proteins are highly conserved (Figure 2).292 Importantly, the conservation of sequence and basic predicted features extends to adenoviruses 293 isolated from great apes and classified as members of species HAdV-B (Figure S4). The ELM tool 294 predicted E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ to be type I transmembrane proteins with a large N-terminal 295 domain and a short C-terminal tail. At the N-terminal domain both proteins have a signal sequences 296 and putative N-glycosylation sites. At the extreme C-terminus both proteins have a highly 297 conserved di-leucine motif (LL) followed by a class II PSD95/DLG/ZO-1 (PDZ) binding motif 298 (PBM) (consensus sequence XΦXΦ, where X = any amino acid, and Φ = any hydrophobic amino acid) (Figure 2). The C-terminal domain of E3-CR1β also has a canonical tyrosine-based 300 sorting motif (YXXΦ, where X = any amino acid, and Φ = any hydrophobic amino acid) which 301 is conserved among all the examined HAdV-B types except SAdV-21, SAdV-35.2, and SAdV-302 27 (Figure S4). The Src Homology 3 (SH3) domain binding motif (PXXP, where X is any amino 303 acid) at the C-terminal domain of E3-CR1β is present in all of the examined HAdV-B types with 304 the exception of HAdV-14 and HAdV-55 (Figures 2 and S4).

At various times pi total RNA was extracted to investigate the presence of E3-20.1K 310 and E3-20.5K-containing transcripts by end point PCR (Figure 3A), infected cells lysates were 311 examined by WB analysis (Figure 3B) or infected cell monolayers on coverslips were fixed and 312 stained for immunofluorescence microspcopy (Figure 4). At 48 hpi when the levels of 327 expression of both proteins peaked, the two E3 proteins co-localized predominantly at the plasma 328 membrane (Figure 4B). The localization of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K to the plasma membrane 329 was confirmed by detection of co-localization of the two proteins with E-cadherin (Figures S6 330 and S7, Panel E). To validate our observations of subcellular localization, we co-transfected 331 pMT2-PL mammalian expression vectors encoding VSV-G E3-20.1K and HA E3-20.5K (Figure 332 S3A) into HEK 293T cells. Consistent with the observations in infected A549 cells, both E3-333 20.1K and E3-20.5K co-localized predominantly to the plasma membrane of transfected HEK 334 293T cells (Figure S8).

In addition, we either mutated or deleted the predicted functional motifs identified in the 353 cytoplasmic tail of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K. As shown in Figure 6, obliteration of the di-leucine motifs (LL/AA mutant) 355 or deletion of the class II PBM (ΔPBM mutant) did not alter the localization of E3-20.1K or E3-356 20.5K (Figure 6A, 6B, and 6C). However, the presence of the 359 TM domain was sufficient to direct both N-terminal and C-terminal domains of E3-20.1K and 360 E3-20.5K to the plasma membrane (Figure 6E and 6G).

FIGREF17.text: HAdV-3 N-tag wt at a MOI of 10 pfu/cell. At 48 hpi cell lysates were treated with PNGase 364 F, α2-3,6,8,9 neuraminidase A, and O-glycosidase either individually or sequentially (Figure 7). 365 Untreated E3-20.1K migrates at approximately 40 kDa. Treatment with PNGase F resulted in an 366 electrophoretic mobility shift to approximately 20 kDa, the predicted size of the translationally 367 unmodified polypeptide, indicating the presence of N-glycosylation. Treatment with α2-, and O-glycosidase resulted in the migration of E3-20.1K at approximately 20 371 kDa, like after PNGase F treatment (Figure 7) indicating that E3-20.1K is N-but not O-372 glycosylated. Untreated E3-20.5K migrated at approximately 40 and 25 kDa, likely as a result of 373 differential glycosylation or partial glycosylation. Treatment with PNGase F resulted in a 374 mobility shift of both bands to approximately 35 kDa and 20 kDa, respectively indicating 375 presence of N-glycosylation. The 20 kDa band represents the predicted size of the translationally 376 unmodified E3-20.5K polypeptide. Treatment with α2-3,6,8,9 neuraminidase A individually, or 377 sequential treatment with α2-3,6,8,9 neuraminidase A and O-glycosidase resulted in the mobility 378 shift of the 40 kDa band only, without affecting the 25 kDa band. However, sequential treatment 379 with PNGase F, α2-3,6,8,9 neuraminidase A, and O-glycosidase resulted in complete 380 deglycosylation and migration of both bands at approximately 20 kDa (Figure 7). This result is in 381 agreement with that reported by Hawkins and colleagues (Hawkins and Wold, 1995) and shows 382 that E3-20.5 K is both N-and O-glycosylated.

FIGREF18.text: HAdV-3 E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K interact with each other384    The observation of co-localization of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K at the plasma membrane in385 infected/transfected cells prompted us to examine whether these proteins physically interact with 386 each other. HEK 293T cells were transfected with pMT2-PL mammalian expression vectors 387 encoding VSV-G E3-20.1K and HA E3-20.5K either individually or together. At 72 hpt, cells 388 were lysed and immunoprecipitated with antibodies specific to either VSV-G or HA to pull down 389 E3-20.1K or E3-20.5K, respectively. The immunoprecipitated proteins were analyzed by WB to 390 evaluate if VSV-G E3-20.1K pulled down HA E3-20.5K and vice versa.Figure 8shows that VSV-G E3-20.1K and HA E3-20.5K co-immunoprecipitated with each other indicating that the 392 two proteins do interact.

FIGREF19.text: E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K do not appear to play a role in HAdV-3 progeny release and in394    HAdV-3 spread in A549 cells395    We next examined the role of HAdV-3 E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K in virus progeny release 396 from infected A549 cells. We generated a double knock out virus (HAdV-3 N-tag DKO) that397 does not express E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K proteins (Figure S2A and S2B). A549 cells were 398 infected with HAdV-3 wt, HAdV-3 N-tag wt or, HAdV-3 N-tag DKO mutant virus at a MOI of 399 1 pfu/cell. At different times pi the extracellular compartment (supernatant) (Figure 9A) or whole 400 dish contents (total virus: cell monolayer and supernatant) (Figure 9B) were sampled to 401 determine infectious virus loads. We observed no difference in infectious virus titers in either the 402 extracellular compartment or in the total virus yields between cells infected with HAdV-3 wt, 403 HAdV-3 N-tag wt, or HAdV-3 N-tag DKO. The contribution of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K to 404 HAdV-3 spread in cell culture was evaluated using a dissemination assay and by examination of 405 plaque phenotypes. We observed no differences in viral spread phenotype (Figure 9C), or in 406 plaque size and morphology (Figure S9) between wt and DKO-infected cells. of work provides a foundational characterization of HAdV-3-encoded E3-CR1β 410 and E3-CR1γ. These HAdV-B-specific E3-CR1 proteins are conserved among human and simian 411 types and present in all examined genomes indicating that they are highly likely to contribute to 412 virus-host interactions occurring during infection. In infected A549 cells the two proteins were 413 readily detectable at late times post infection, presumably as a result of translation of MLP transcripts. The results of our recent studies determining the critical contribution of the TPL 415 sequence to the successful ectopic expression of HAdV-B and HAdV-E E3 CR1 genes (Bair et 416 al., 2017) suggest that the presence of this non-coding element is essential for efficient 417 translation of HAdV-3 E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K transcripts at late times post infection. 418 Our data show that E3-20.1K is only N-glycosylated while, as previously reported by Hawkins 419 and Wold (Hawkins and Wold, 1995), HAdV-3 E3-20.5K is both N-and O-glycosylated. We 420 also conclusively demonstrate that E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K are type I transmembrane proteins 421 that co-localize predominantly to the cytoplasmic vesicles at 24 hpi and to the plasma membrane 422 at 48 hpi in non-polarized epithelial cells (A549 and HEK 293Ts). 423 A thorough examination of the subcellular localization of these proteins by confocal 424 fluorescence microscopy at 24 hpi revealed that at steady-state both proteins localize to the ER, 425 TGN, and early endosomes but not to the late endosomes/lysosomes. These results suggest that 426 E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K traffic to the plasma membrane along the secretory pathway. 427 Interestingly, we observed that a considerable proportion of the detectable E3-20.1K and E3-428 20.5K at 24 hpi localized to cytoplasmic vesicles that could not be identified by our efforts. This 429 suggests that the proteins may be delivered to the plasma membrane by secretory vesicles or by 430 unconventional pathways including secretory autophagy (Cotzomi-Ortega et al., 2018) 431 warranting additional studies using an expanded panel of markers. The fact that E3-20.1K and 432 E3-20.5K co-immunoprecipitate suggests that these proteins may work together to carry out their 433 biological functions. 434 In a recent study of the HAdV E3-CR1 host extracellular interactome using C-terminal IgG 435 Fc fusion of the E3 CR1 protein ectodomains as baits and an extracellular protein microarray, interacts with the signaling lymphocyte activation molecule (SLAM) family of receptors and 438 inhibits T-cell activation. The N-terminal domain of HAdV-B E3-CR1γ was also shown to 439 interact with SLAM receptors, although the functional implications of this interaction were not 440 investigated (Martinez-Martin et al., 2016). Our study shows that the C-termini of both E3-20.1K 441 and E3-20.5K have a class II PBM suggesting that these proteins may carry out additional 442 functions within the host cell through interactions with PDZ proteins. Multiple sequence analysis 443 indicates that the class II PBM is conserved among the E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ proteins of all of 444 simian and human members of species HAdV-B. 445 The LL motif was found in all of the examined HAdV-B E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ proteins. 446 The YXXΦ motif is present in all of the E3-CR1β proteins encoded by human types and in most 447 of the E3-CR1β proteins encoded by simian members of the species. Interestingly, while the 448 YXXΦ motif is also present in many of the E3-CR1γ proteins encoded by simian HAdV-B, it is 449 not present in any of the E3-CR1γ encoded by human types classified within this species. The 450 LL and YXXΦ motifs are sorting signals that aid in the trafficking of proteins through the 451 secretory pathway and in the targeting of membrane proteins to the basolateral surface of 452 polarized epithelial cells (Heilker et al., 1999; Miranda et al., 2001). Like the LL motif in HAdV-453 D-specific E3-49K, the LL motif in HAdV-B E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ does not fit the consensus 454 sequence of acidic (D/E)XXXL(L/I) or DXXLL di-leucine motifs (Windheim et al., 2016). The 455 LL motif of HAdV-D E3-49K was shown to be important for trafficking of the full length 456 protein and the C-terminal portion of the cleaved protein from the cell surface to the early 457 endosome/trans Golgi network (TGN) and lysosomes, respectively (Windheim et al., 2016). Our 458 observations of subcellular localization of ectopically-expressed mutant versions of HAdV-3 E3-459 20.1K and E3-20.5K indicate that, at least in our experimental system, obliteration of the LL motif or deletion of the class II PBM did not affect the localization of these proteins to the 461 plasma membrane. Likewise, deletion of the N-terminal or C-terminal domains while retaining 462 the transmembrane domain did not alter the localization of E3-20.1K and E3-20.5K. These 463 results indicate that the TM domain of these proteins is sufficient for localization to the plasma 464 membrane and that neither the LL nor the class II PBM nor the YXXΦ motifs play a critical role 465 in their trafficking to the plasma membrane in non-polarized cells. 466The presence of a class II PBMs in the extreme C-termini of HAdV-B E3-CR1β and E3-467 CR1γ has not been previously reported. The identified PBMs have the typical 4-amino acid 468 length and the localization described for PBMs in general and are therefore anticipated to be 469 functional(Hung and Sheng, 2002; Nourry et al., 2003). The PBM has the potential to confer 470 these HAdV-B-specific E3-CR1 proteins the ability to interact with PDZ-domain containing host 471 proteins and therefore deserves further investigation for elucidation of functional implications.472Our thorough examination of E3-CR1 protein sequences for a wide range of HAdV types 473 representing species HAdV-A through -G identified a putative class II PBM (-SLTV COOH ), at the 474 extreme C-terminus of E3-CR1β/11.6K encoded by various strains of HAdV-C5 (AC_000008, 475 AY601635, KX868466, KF429754, MF681662 among others) but intriguingly, not by E3-476 CR1β/11.6K of types HAdV-C1, -C2 and -C6 (data not shown). We also observed that the C-477 termini of E3-CR1α proteins encoded by HAdV-D8 (AB448769), -D9 (AJ854486), -D15 478 (AB562586), -D19 (AB448774), -D37 (AB448778), -D46 (AY875648), -D56 (HM770721), and 479 -D64 (EF121005) possess a class III PBM (consensus sequence (D/E)XΦ, where X = any amino 480 acid, and Φ = hydrophobic amino acid) (data not shown).

FIGREF20.text: In humans, PDZ domains are found in over 200 proteins that primarily contribute to the 482 generation and maintenance of cell-cell junctions and cell polarity, or that are involved in cellular signal transduction pathways.(Assemat et al., 2008; Spaller, 2006). Several viral 484 proteins are known to encode PBMs that target host PDZ domain-containing proteins to485 modulate cellular processes in support of virus replication, viral pathogenesis, and virus 486 dissemination or transmission to new host (Javier and Rice, 2011). For example, adenovirus E4-487 ORF1 contains a class I PBM (-ATLV COOH ) through which E4-ORF1 binds PDZ domain 488 containing proteins to disrupt epithelial cell junctions of infected cells (Latorre et al., 2005). The 489 SARS coronavirus envelope protein E contains a Class II PBM (-DLLV COOH ) that mediates the 490 interaction of the protein with PALS1, affecting tight junction formation in infected cells (Teoh 491 et al., 2010). 492 Our results show that unlike the HAdV-C-specific E3-CR1β/ADP (Tollefson et al., 1996a; 493 Tollefson et al., 1996b), HAdV-3-encoded E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ do not play a role in virus 494 progeny release, cell-to-cell spread or plaque formation in non-polarized cells. However, the 495 subcellular localization of E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ as well as their contribution to virus progeny 496 release and their effect on epithelial barrier integrity should be re-examined in polarized 497 epithelial cells. By using our HAdV-3 mutants in a more physiologically relevant experimental 498 system, the role of these two CR1 proteins during the HAdV-B's life cycle may be more easily 499 unveiled and protein-protein interactions more accurately localized to specific cellular domains. 500 The Syrian hamster recently shown by Radke and colleagues (Radke et al., 2016) to support 501 replication of HAdV-14, a member of species HAdV-B, is an interesting animal model to be 502 considered for the examination of the role of E3-CR1β and E3-CR1γ during infection in vivo.503The detection of HAdV-14 hexon protein in the lungs of infected hamsters suggests that E3-CR1 504 proteins would be expressed at detectable levels in this host, opening new opportunities for viral 505 pathogenesis studies.
